Quantum mechanics is a beautiful and powerful theory, but its foundations are unclear. This paper provides a new perspective on the foundations of quantum theory. We show that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. This result is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. It is therefore applicable to any theory that can be formulated as a category with a notion of continuity. The result has implications for the reconstruction of quantum mechanics from its observations, and for the foundations of quantum information theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of great interest because of their extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. Here, we report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals and that the group has undergone a remarkable reduction in gene content. In addition, we find that myxozoans have lost many signaling and transcriptional factors that are important for development in other animals. These results suggest that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic myxozoan was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. This is an important step in understanding the evolution of parasitism. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is one of the main factors that determine the success of their infection. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2 in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a deeper understanding of the mechanisms by which SARS-CoV-2 evades the host immune response and may help in the development of new strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the global food demand will increase by 50% to meet the needs of the growing population. However, the optimum growing temperature for maize is close to the current global mean temperature, and the temperature is expected to increase by 2 °C to 4 °C by the end of the century. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability that the world’s major maize-exporting countries have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. This will have important implications for global grain trade and international grain prices, especially for the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because species-level identification is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. We found that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest overlap in diet composition, but that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses are uncertain about the length of the crisis, and some anticipate that they will not survive the next few months.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly due to size-selective sinks. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the origin of the solar system. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar exposure ages of <300 Ma and ages of >1 Ga. The grains with ages of >1 Ga are a challenge to the current theory of the formation of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has increased exponentially. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide resources to offspring correlates with an increase in reproductive output. We find that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the number of offspring produced rather than an increase in the number of reproductive events. This suggests that the limiting factor on reproductive output is the mother’s metabolic power rather than resource availability.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder with a high mortality rate. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in the striatum of a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and its oligomers, and with neuroprotective effects in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This would be the first disease-modifying therapy for this orphan disease. (Read more)

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the primary interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is a highly specialized cell type that controls vascular function and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The endothelium is the target of many drugs and is the focus of many diseases. The communication network of the endothelium is poorly understood, and the nature of the communication channels is unknown. Here, we use a combination of imaging and mathematical modeling to reveal the nature of the communication network of the endothelium. The endothelium is shown to be a highly connected, small-world network that is effective in both local and global communication. The findings have implications for the design of communication networks in general and for the design of communication networks in the body.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are being used to monitor and respond to the pandemic. However, the data are often not available in a form that is easily accessible to the public, and the data that are available are often not comparable across sources. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not available elsewhere. The data are available in a common format, and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the data can be used to monitor the pandemic, and to augment traditional public health reporting. The data and software are available to the public.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes and are the target of many drugs. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the channel’s selectivity. The selectivity filter is also the most dynamic part of the channel, and its structural changes are the basis for the channel’s gating. We have identified a key residue for the functional and structural coupling between the selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels. We have also demonstrated that the selectivity filter can be used as a structural switch for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. This work provides a new perspective on the gating of potassium channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for health. The role of the anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, peptides, and polyketides. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are important contributors to the gut microbiome and could be used as a source of natural products.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the development of social hierarchy is poorly understood. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate in a social encounter with a low-anxious rat and that this is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals can be reversed by pharmacological interventions. Our findings highlight the importance of mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens for social behavior and point to mitochondrial energy metabolism as a potential target for the treatment of anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple materials and their optimal arrangement. The structures are digitally designed to seamlessly collaborate to achieve arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and exhibit highly nonlinear responses in experiments. The proposed approach can be extended to design structures with complex behaviors and navigability. The design space is expanded to include structures with multiple material phases and their optimal arrangement, which can be utilized to design multifunctional devices with specific target behaviors. The hemoglobin system is a key component of the oxygen transport system in the human body. The hemoglobin system is also a target of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key element in the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is downregulated in the adult bone marrow. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. This suggests a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This is the first demonstration of a role for IGF2BP1 in the hemoglobin system.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite the development of new therapies, the prognosis of many cancer patients remains poor. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer cell resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through the transcriptional regulation of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a key enzyme in lipid metabolism. This mechanism of resistance is highly prevalent in cancer, and the combination of mTOR inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. Our findings may lead to the development of new cancer therapies. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the prevention of heart failure. The major drug class for treating hypertension is the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). LCCBs are widely used in the treatment of hypertension, but the mechanism of action of LCCBs is not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the action of LCCBs and may lead to the development of new drugs for the treatment of hypertension. This article is protected by copyright. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the United States. It was science-based, incorporated adaptive management, and was the first plan to use a land-ownership map to guide management. We show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of early-seral ecosystems, but that the policy has failed to reverse the decline of older forests. This failure is partly due to the fact that the NWFP did not halt clearcutting on federal land, which continues to be a major threat to older forests. The NWFP is a model for policy makers and managers, and our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the plan.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making it difficult to train the network on large datasets. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. This makes the network architecture easier to train and apply in practice.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common, but the biological effects of such technology use on sleep are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin and has a negative impact on sleep, as measured by the time to fall asleep, the amount of sleep, and the timing of the circadian clock. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the Younger Dryas cooling at ∼12.9 ka. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio have 187Os/188Os ratios ≥1.0, similar to average upper continental crust (= 1.3), indicating a terrestrial origin of osmium (Os) in these samples. The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to the development of a variety of autoinflammatory diseases, including autoimmunity against the thymus, pancreas, and salivary glands. These diseases are accompanied by the development of autoantibodies, which is a hallmark of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of genes from 521 species to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origin of the group, the diversification of beetle lineages, and the evolution of their digestive systems. Our results suggest that beetles diversified in a warm, wet world, and that the evolution of their digestive systems was key to the group’s success.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs), which have shown increased transmissibility and immune evasion. The emergence of these variants has highlighted the need for new therapeutics to combat the pandemic. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach by improving the potency and breadth of an antibody that is effective against the current variants but not the emerging VOCs. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules and can potentially be used to develop new therapeutics to combat the pandemic. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help in the development of new therapeutics to combat the pandemic. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of cooperation, the spread of ideas, and the development of technology. They also have implications for the design of social systems.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 increases risk by ∼12-fold. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is legal in some states, it remains illegal at the federal level. The legal status of marijuana is a political and social issue that is debated in the United States and around the world. The present study provides evidence that the brain’s response to the drug is also highly variable.

Language is a uniquely human ability, enabling communication, culture, and cognition. The brain’s language comprehension system is complex and poorly understood. Here, we show that the most accurate computational models of language processing in the field also predict a large fraction of variance in the brain responses of native language users. Our results provide computational and neuroscientific support for a key aspect of the language comprehension system: its dependence on predicting the next word in a sentence. These findings have implications for understanding the brain’s mechanisms of language comprehension, learning a language as a new user, and dyslexia, a disorder of language comprehension.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it is still in its infancy. One of the main reasons is that the stability of DL is still an open problem. We prove that there are cases where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train such a network. This is a fundamental result that will help us understand the limits of machine learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. The scientific community has been working hard to understand the virus and its spread. One of the most prominent arguments is that people’s inability to understand exponential growth is the main reason for the pandemic. This argument is based on a classic experiment published 45 years ago. Despite its critical design flaws, the study is often cited, but its conclusions are ignored. This article discusses the flaws of the study and its implications for science and society.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are responsible for the two major forms of the disease, namely, lepromatous and lepromatous-like leprosy. The genomes of these two species are now available, and we have compared them. We find that the two species are remarkably similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions, despite their ancient separation. This suggests that the two species are still capable of causing disease, and that the differences between them are likely to be of little clinical significance. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the keystones of quantum information theory, where they are at the heart of quantum communication and quantum computation. However, the entanglement dynamics is a very difficult problem, which is only partially understood. Here, we show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our work is a major step toward the understanding of the entanglement dynamics in general systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that has affected millions of people worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the only way to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is based on a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain that has been codon-optimized to reduce its virulence. The vaccine candidate is easy to manufacture, can be stored at 2–8 °C, and can be administered by the intranasal route, which is the most effective route of administration for SARS-CoV-2. The vaccine candidate is highly protective in hamsters and can be used in mass vaccination programs. This vaccine candidate is a promising candidate for the global fight against COVID-19. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, with multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but the historical spread of plague is poorly understood. Here, we use a compartmental model to describe the spread of plague by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by human ectoparasites during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), challenging the assumption that plague was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a new perspective on the history of plague in Europe.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is less studied. Here, we show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also different from that of body size. We show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only different from that of brain size but also different from that of body size.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (Read more)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin severes filaments is not known. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin binds to filaments more efficiently in regions of high curvature, but severing is enhanced by mechanical tension. We propose that the mechanical torque induced by filament anchoring enhances severing by increasing the rate constant of the reaction. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding severing in cells and for developing new strategies to target ADF/cofilin in disease. (Show more)

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in the food supply and is known to be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes greater hunger and desire for food and a greater willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose and may promote overeating.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. Here, we use a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its genomic diversity. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent and sex-biased colonization from Africa and Asia. In addition, we find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the settlement history of Madagascar. We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. This finding has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social networks.

The ribosome is a complex machine that translates messenger RNAs into proteins. The ribosome is composed of two subunits, the large and small, and each of these subunits is composed of many smaller parts. The ribosome is able to read the sequence of messenger RNAs and translate it into a protein. The ribosome is able to do this because messenger RNAs are modified in many different ways. One of the most common modifications is the addition of a sugar ring to a specific nucleotide. This sugar ring is called a pseudouridine. We show that the presence of pseudouridine can have a modest effect on the translation of messenger RNAs. This finding has implications for how we understand the function of messenger RNAs and the ribosome. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is meaningful and worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of health and behavioral outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to the effects of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, or to outcome levels before the measurement of worthwhile ratings. The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may promote health and well-being at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal clades. The aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes by constraining the size of the aquatic realm.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature, but the mechanism of this temperature dependence is not known. Here we show that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus more efficiently at body temperature than at cool temperature, and that this temperature dependence is dependent on the RIG-I–like receptor antiviral defense pathway. These findings have implications for understanding the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication in the nose and for the development of antiviral strategies for the common cold. (Read more)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses its type IV pili as a sensor to detect the mechanical activity of the pili, and use this information to regulate its virulence. This is a unique mechanism that allows the bacteria to sense the mechanical activity of the pili, and use this information to regulate its virulence. This is a remarkable example of how bacteria can use their own structures as sensors to regulate their behavior.

The global spread of pesticides has led to a substantial increase in the number of aquatic species affected by pesticide contamination. However, the extent of the problem is not fully understood because of a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global assessment of the risk of pesticide contamination to aquatic biodiversity. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, including wildlife, and the potential for spillback into humans is a major concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is widespread in North America. Deer are susceptible to infection and can transmit the virus to other deer. Our findings highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology and evolution of SARS-CoV-2, as well as the need for a “One Health” approach to prevent spillback into humans. This will be critical to the successful management of the pandemic. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that is affecting the lives of millions of people. The paper examines the causes of the problem, the impacts of the dams, and the solutions that are needed. The paper also proposes a new approach to hydropower that can be used to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatment is a major public health concern. The disease is characterized by chronic inflammation, which is most often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to amyloid-β (Aβ) plaque deposits and cell death. However, this response is not observed in animal models of AD devoid of such pathologies, suggesting that the underlying processes may be different in the earliest stages of the disease. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type in the brain, are also the source of an inflammatory response in AD. This finding is significant because it suggests that the accumulation of soluble and oligomeric Aβ, rather than the formation of Aβ plaques, may be the primary cause of the AD-related inflammation. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a critical target for the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Read more)

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was practiced there as early as the fourth century B.C.E. This is the earliest known evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens in the world.

The folding of large proteins is a major challenge in understanding protein structure and function. The folding of the large maltose binding protein (MBP) is a model system for studying the folding of proteins with a complex sequence. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of MBP at high structural resolution. The method is based on the use of hydrogen exchange to monitor the folding of MBP in the presence of a large number of labeled residues. The results show that the folding of MBP is a multistep process. The folding intermediates are distinct and are not the same as the native state. The results are important for understanding the folding of large proteins. They also provide a model for the folding of other proteins. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. The predominant decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in cells experiencing such stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unique manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a major health problem, and the development of new therapeutic strategies is needed. We show that arginine, a key amino acid, is depleted in sepsis and that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is an effective strategy to restore arginine availability and immune function. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is the sum of the masses of all the organisms that inhabit the planet. It is a fundamental quantity that is used to understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of the biomass of different taxa is still lacking. Here, we assemble the biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. This article is protected by copyright. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems can exhibit criticality without external control. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, without defects or impurities, by applying strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, without defects or impurities, by applying pressure. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. The role of plant immune system in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the role of the immune system in the defense against bacteria and viruses is less clear. Here, we show that a plant immune peptide from the legume Medicago truncatula has a fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The peptide binds to multiple phosphoinositides in vitro and in planta, and induces reactive oxygen species in germlings of the fungal pathogen. The peptide also binds to the fungal cell wall, and induces membrane permeabilization and loss of turgor in germlings. The peptide is effective in controlling gray mold disease in tomato and tobacco plants. This work provides evidence for the role of plant immune peptides in the defense against plant fungal pathogens. It also provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of plant immune peptides. This knowledge can be used for the development of a new class of fungicides. (Read more)

The male–female reproductive axis is the fundamental unit of sexual reproduction. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the sperm proteome, and that these contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of male–female interactions and reproductive success. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, to control bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to platelets switches the VWF A1 domain to a second state with faster binding kinetics. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD, and the effects of mutations in VWF. The force-induced conformational switch is a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. The force-induced conformational switch is a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the viral component of the microbiome, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for the human virome, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health. We find that viruses are associated with a wide variety of diseases, including cancer, diabetes, and neurodegenerative diseases. This study provides a resource for future studies of the human virome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the complexity of ACI makes it difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the observational capability is inadequate. This study introduces a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to overcome this conundrum. The instrument can simultaneously profile aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. The instrument was verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques. The instrument was operated to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of the instrument to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been the subject of intense debate for more than a century. The temperature inferred from isotopic evidence is in conflict with the temperature inferred from protein reconstruction. Here, we show that the ancestral environmental temperatures of organisms reconstructed to inhabit the photic zone of ancient oceans are consistent with the temperature of the surface of the Earth. This finding provides a new method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth over geological time.

Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow and cell function. The pore gate of K+ channels is the main site of ion flow and is composed of two gates, one for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel lacks an intracellular activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help us understand the function of K+ channels and may also provide a new approach for drug development. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding would suggest that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and could lead to the development of new strategies to combat the disease. (Show more)

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The impact of environmental factors on influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for understanding the impact of environmental factors on influenza virus infection and disease outcome in the wild, and may lead to the development of new strategies for influenza vaccine and antiviral therapy. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how this process unfolds in the brain remains unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power in multiple superior temporal and inferior frontal regions increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This process may be essential for language comprehension and production.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the canonical Wnt pathway. This is an important feature that may be common in other redundant gene pairs in vertebrates.

Obesity is a major health problem, and the search for new treatments is ongoing. Here we describe a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit is located in the lateral hypothalamus, where it is composed of neurons that project to the ventral tegmental area and to the substantia nigra. Stimulation of this circuit in the lateral hypothalamus causes animals to eat more than normal, and this effect is blocked by lesions of the ventral tegmental area or the substantia nigra. This circuit may be a target for future treatments of obesity.

Nitrogen is the primary limiting nutrient for plant growth and productivity. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and their bacteria would allow for the delivery of nitrogen in a sustainable and efficient manner. Here, we have developed a system for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to deliver nitrogen in a sustainable and efficient manner. This work also represents a proof of principle for the use of transkingdom signaling in the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. The Peruvian Amazon is one of the most deforested regions in the world. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, early deforestation alerts rarely reach the most directly affected communities in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius has an auditory organ that is not part of its body but is made of its protein web. The web acts as an acoustic antenna, and the spider can remotely sense and localize the direction of sound by sensing the motion of the web. The spider can also adjust and regenerate its web to suit its needs. This study provides insights into the evolution of hearing and the outsourcing of sensing functions. It also provides a unique model for studying the sensing of fluid dynamics. (Show more)

The health and climate impacts of anthropogenic emissions are difficult to disentangle. We use a global model to estimate the climate and health benefits of a phaseout of fossil fuels, and the trade-offs between climate and health. We find that a phaseout of fossil fuels can save 3.61 million lives per year, and that the aerosol component of air pollution is responsible for 70% of the climate cooling. The model shows that aerosols and fossil-fuel-related emissions are the main contributors to the rise in global temperature. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to claim lives and disrupt economies worldwide. The global distribution of vaccines is uneven, and many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) lack access to vaccines. We report a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that is well-suited for inclusion in a subunit vaccine. This variant exhibits improved manufacturability and immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 sequence used in current vaccines. This engineered sequence may be useful in the development of subunit vaccines for COVID-19 and other diseases. The engineered RBD may also be useful in the development of subunit vaccines for other coronaviruses, such as those causing Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS). This engineered RBD may also be useful in the development of subunit vaccines for other diseases, such as influenza. (See all things simplified)

The role of the ALK receptor in development is well established. However, the ligand(s) for the ALK family of receptors are still unknown. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK-like proteins (ALKals) are ligands for ALK receptors. We further show that ALKals are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our results provide evidence for a role of ALK receptors in the development of neural crest-derived tissues in vivo. This study provides a new model for the study of ALK receptor function in development. It also provides a potential target for the development of new therapeutics. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it has been responsible for multiple pandemics. The earliest Yersinia pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have revealed key evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Y. pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. However, the number of genomes is too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia, which allowed us to explore correlations between temporal, geographical, and genetic distance. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work highlights the importance of masculinity as a cultural ideology in understanding the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. We show that men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—predicted voting for and evaluations of Donald Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of masculinity as a cultural ideology in understanding the political behavior of men and women. They also have implications for understanding the political behavior of men and women in other countries.

The agricultural transformation of the 20th century has led to the loss of 100 to 150 Pg of carbon (C) from the global soil carbon pool. This loss has been driven by the conversion of grasslands to cropland and the intensification of crop production. The management of grasslands and livestock can reverse this trend, but the effects of these practices on soil C dynamics are highly uncertain. We show that the management of grasslands and livestock can increase soil C storage and that the effects of these practices are dependent on the type of soil, the type of crop, and the management of the crop. These results highlight the potential of grasslands and livestock to mitigate climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of zoonotic spillover and spread of novel viruses in wildlife. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for spillover and spread in humans and developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, to estimate the risk of 887 wildlife viruses. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world. The tool can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a framework for systematically identifying and prioritizing targets for research and public health interventions.

Nectar is the reward that flowering plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait for attracting pollinators, but the mechanisms by which this trait is evolved remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a second alkaloid, nesocodonine, in the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus. We demonstrate that nesocodin is attractive to the gecko pollinators of N. mauritianus, and provide evidence that this trait is convergent in the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergently evolved trait that is likely to be favored by natural selection. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–animal interaction. (Show more)

The history of Europe is marked by a series of migrations and invasions, which have shaped the genetic landscape of the continent. However, the genetic history of the period between the migrations of the Huns and the Roman withdrawal is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived during the 6th century. Our results indicate that they had a genetic ancestry that was not present in the modern population, and that they differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The global spread of infectious diseases is a major public health concern. The emergence of new pathogens and the spread of existing ones are a constant threat to human health. The rapid identification of pathogens is critical to the development of effective public health responses. Metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a powerful tool for pathogen identification, but its application in resource-limited settings is limited. We describe the use of mNGS in a resource-scarce setting in Cambodia, where we identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS in resource-limited settings and the potential for its application in the early detection of emerging pathogens. This approach can be used to identify the regional pathogen landscape and the deployment of rapid public health response. (Show more)

The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. However, the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for lagging strand synthesis. This knowledge is critical for understanding the role of pol δ in human diseases. The origin of life is one of the most important questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of genetically encoded proteins, the replication of genetic information was accomplished by RNA polymerases, which were likely ribozymes. In this study, we demonstrate that an RNA polymerase ribozyme can be evolved to synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a foundation for the study of the origin of life and the evolution of nucleic acids. (Show more)

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies. In this paper, we use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods over time. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that urban change is a complex process that is influenced by a variety of factors. This complexity is likely to be important for understanding the future of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. The immune characteristics of patients with severe COVID-19 were analyzed, and the therapeutic strategy was proposed. The results show that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic. The fungal xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) has been shown to bind copper, but the role of the BGC in copper homeostasis has not been established. Here we show that the xan BGC is expressed in Aspergillus fumigatus, and that the xan BGC isocyanide products bind copper. Copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of xan BGC isocyanide products were demonstrated in vitro and in vivo. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the evolution of fungal natural products and their role in the maintenance of copper homeostasis. (Read more)

Frost is a major environmental factor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of frost events are poorly understood. We show that the common garden distribution of leaf-out and leaf-freezing resistance traits in woody species is consistent with the species’ frost risk in their native regions. Our findings reveal that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the current frost regime. This information can be used to inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of these diseases is unclear. Here, we show that Th17 cells can induce colitis in a Stat4-dependent manner. However, Th17 cells are unable to induce colitis in recipients lacking IFN-γ. Instead, the development of disease requires the development of Th1-like cells, which are dependent on Stat4 and T-bet. These results suggest that Th17 cells can act as both direct effectors of disease and as a source of “helper” cells that can induce the development of other cell types. This dual role may be important in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease. (Read more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by the degeneration of motor neurons, the cells that control voluntary muscle movement. The disease is progressive, and death is usually within 3 to 5 years. The disease is fatal because motor neurons are not replaced. We now report a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This method enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will help us to understand the disease mechanism and develop therapeutics. This is a major advance in ALS research.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum. We now show that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota to enhance its transmission. We demonstrate that Anaplasma induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the composition of the tick microbiota. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an antifreeze protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This study provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector to enhance transmission. This knowledge may be useful in the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short tail of modern birds is thought to have evolved from a long tail ending in a compound bone (pygostyle) in the group Pygostylia. However, the known diversity of early members of Pygostylia is limited, making it difficult to understand the origin of the modern avian tail. Here, we describe a new basal member of Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, and show that it represents the second earliest diverging group of Pygostylia. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases our understanding of the origin of the avian tail and the evolution of mosaic evolution in early birds. (Show more)

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand its behavior. One of the most important aspects of the climate system is the role of water vapor, which is a key ingredient in the water cycle. Here we show that water vapor variations play an important role in the climate system, and that this role is not limited to the water vapor feedback. Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for camouflage, communication, and other functions. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution, and that the mechanism of color change is the same in all cases. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most ubiquitous group of proteins in vertebrates. Our results provide a molecular and functional basis for the evolution of color in vertebrates. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The identification of factors that determine the proportion of cancer cells that are cancer stem cells (CSCs) is important for the development of new therapies. We report that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the proportion of breast cancer cells that are CSCs. This study provides a mechanism for the role of hypoxia in the development of CSCs and may lead to the development of new therapies for breast cancer. (Read more)

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. It is also one of the most fragile. The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was easily torn. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment in the future. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. The age model presented here is based on a precise age model for the Permian-Triassic boundary and the age of the extinction. The age model is based on a detailed analysis of the carbon cycle and the timing of the extinction is consistent with the hypothesis that it was triggered by a combination of global environmental perturbation and a collapse of the carbon cycle. The age model provides a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Less)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. IBD is a complex disease with a high incidence and a high rate of recurrence. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and not fully understood. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We show that the D614G mutation is associated with a range of more open conformations of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. This study provides a detailed structural comparison of the spike protein in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation, which may help to inform the development of future vaccines and therapeutics.
