We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate the impact of the pandemic on life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our projections imply that the Black−White life expectancy gap will increase from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. The Latino or Hispanic paradox, which has been a source of hope for health equity, will be lost. These projections should be considered in the context of the ongoing pandemic.

The study of the chemical properties of matter under pressure is of fundamental importance, as it is the only way to understand the origin of the chemical phenomena observed in the Earth and the universe. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we discover that the pseudo–noble-gas configuration is achieved at high pressure. We also show that the chemical properties of the elements can be predicted with high accuracy. This work is a step forward in the understanding of the chemical properties of matter under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can have important consequences for the global carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of this effect is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between climate, fire, and carbon cycle. We show that human demography, rather than climate, is the dominant driver of changes in global fire activity. This has the potential to reduce warming, but only if human demography is reduced. Our results suggest that the effects of climate change on fire activity may be more important than previously thought.

The immune system of animals is often associated with the production of a large number of different molecules, many of which are secreted into the environment. In this study, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, by the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. Chitin is catabolized by the symbiont only at night, when the squid is active, and this activity is required for the periodic acidification of the crypts, which is essential for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the immune system and their potential to regulate the activities of symbiotic microbes. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We draw on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This approach can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos.

The Black Death, the deadliest epidemic in history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics were the cause of repeated reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results provide evidence for the existence of a long-distance transmission of the plague bacterium, which was not limited to the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This finding challenges the traditional view of the Black Death as a singular event and suggests that the disease was a persistent threat in the Mediterranean for centuries. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important prey for many species of fish, seabirds, and marine mammals. The recent mass mortality of sea stars on the Pacific coast of North America has led to a decline in the abundance of their prey. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is spreading in the population. The disease has a significant impact on the population, and the virus is likely to have a significant impact on the ecosystem.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. The identification of AML stem cells is important for the development of more efficient therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. Here, we use a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its genomic diversity. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, with a recent and sex-biased colonization from Africa and Asia. In addition, we find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new perspective on the settlement history of Madagascar. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs), which have shown increased transmissibility and immune evasion. The emergence of these variants has highlighted the need for new therapeutics to combat the pandemic. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach by optimizing the binding affinity of an antibody that is effective against the Delta variant but not the Alpha variant. Our approach can be used to optimize the binding affinity of other antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants and potentially be used to develop new therapeutics. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help in the development of new therapeutics to combat the pandemic. (Show more)

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system, and their knowledge is critical to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that the resulting crop condition index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our findings have implications for the design of early warning systems for agricultural production, and for the development of new tools for the monitoring of agricultural production and food security.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a sustained increase in neural activity. However, this view is challenged by evidence that short-term synaptic facilitation may also play a role in memory. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, and we find that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration does not change with warming in most biomes. This result is contrary to the findings of multiple single-site studies, and it suggests that the response of soil respiration to warming may be more complex than previously thought. Our results highlight the importance of understanding the temperature response of soil respiration in different biomes, as this process may play a significant role in the global carbon cycle.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, because the transition is not a discrete event, but rather a gradual process. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle is also a gradual process, and that the evolutionary dynamics of the plastid genome are linked to the gradual relaxation of functional constraints. Our findings have implications for the study of the evolution of the plastid genome, as well as for the study of the evolution of the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the impact of climate change on water availability in South Africa. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the role of anthropogenic climate change in the occurrence of the 2015–2017 drought. We find that the probability of such a drought will increase by a factor of five to six by the year 2100 under a medium-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and by a factor of eight to 10 under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results are important for water resource managers and policy makers in SSA. They also provide a useful example of how climate models can be used to quantify the impact of climate change on water resources. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test, is a story of the power of science to transform our world.

Photosynthesis is the primary process by which life on Earth obtains energy. The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and neuroinflammation is associated with the development of neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the development of autoimmune diseases. Neuroinflammation is known to be regulated by a variety of kinases, but the precise role of each kinase in neuroinflammation remains unknown. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation is regulated by neurokinase ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes. We propose ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. Our study provides a better understanding of the role of neuroinflammation in MS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for MS. This study also provides a foundation for future studies on the role of neuroinflammation in other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest period in the state’s instrumental record and the most extreme drought on record. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is likely due to anthropogenic warming. We also find that the probability of drought years is more than twice as likely to occur when conditions are warm. These findings have important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and wildfire risk in California and elsewhere in the world.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for mapping out causal paths in autism. It also provides a potential target for the development of therapeutics. (Show more)

The news media are often accused of being negative, but the evidence for this accusation is mixed. This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also serves to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, associated with congenital bleeding and myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in Drosophila is dependent on the presence of a defined subset of neurons and that the spread of aggregates is dependent on the presence of a defined subset of neurons. Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic diseases and the potential of bats as a source of novel therapeutics. Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), a key enzyme in one-carbon metabolism. We show that the inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that the inhibitor is effective in cancer cell lines, but not in normal cell lines. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type that is notoriously difficult to treat. Thus, our work identifies a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited for cancer therapy. This work also provides a platform for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. (Read more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. We show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of other neurodegenerative diseases. (Read more)

Cold atoms are a versatile platform for exploring fundamental physics and for applications in quantum technologies. The ability to control the interactions between atoms is a key enabling technology. Here, we present a 2D photonic crystal system for controlling the interactions between cold atoms. The photonic crystal is fabricated from a silicon nitride layer, and the device can be fabricated with high yield. The photonic crystal can be used to control the interactions between atoms, and the device can be used to load atoms into the photonic crystal and control the position of the atoms relative to the photonic crystal. The device can be used to explore many-body physics and to engineer exotic quantum states of matter. The device can also be used for applications in quantum technologies.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the role of aquatic habitats in this diversification is still debated. Here we present a detailed analysis of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous that is sister to Ceratophyllum, a living aquatic plant. Montsechia is an important plant because it is the oldest known aquatic angiosperm, and it opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the early evolution of the flowering plants.

Parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 thousand years ago) and show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is dated to ∼12.6 thousand years ago, and that the recombination event that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level around the world has risen over the last century, but the rate of rise has accelerated in recent decades. This study shows that the acceleration is caused by the warming climate, not by changes in the way the sea level is measured. The acceleration is quantified, and the rate of sea level rise is projected into the future. The results are consistent with the IPCC 5th Assessment Report (AR5) model projections.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States, but that the increase has been greater for those with less education. This is a troubling finding, as it suggests that tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of this defining species, including the location of the water molecule that serves as the hydrogen bond donor in the catalytic reaction. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions, and the importance of the three-dimensional structure of the enzyme–substrate complex for understanding the reaction pathway. This work also demonstrates the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in the study of a reaction that is not amenable to solution NMR spectroscopy. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum inhibitor of viral replication that has been shown to be effective against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic treatment with remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection resulted in a clear clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance in the current global pandemic. Suspension rates in US schools have increased by 50% in the past decade. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic approach to discipline, which can reduce suspension rates and improve students’ respect for teachers. This approach can be taught and sustained through a brief, online intervention. The findings have implications for the design of effective school discipline policies.

Alkylated DNA lesions, induced by both exogenous chemical agents and endogenous metabolites, are major contributors to DNA mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes severe disease in humans. The virus infects human cells by binding to cell receptors and fusing the virion with the cell membrane. The virus requires two sequential proteolytic events to allow binding and fusion. We found that the first cleavage event is important for virus infection into human lung-derived cells, but not into other cell types. This finding suggests that the first cleavage event is important for virus infection into cells that are relevant to lung infection. The first cleavage event may also be important for virus virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to reduce these emissions and improve population health. However, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other diet-related diseases. This study demonstrates that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting can have a large impact on meal selection. This finding has important implications for the food system and for population health. It suggests that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings is a simple and effective way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and improve population health. It also suggests that the physical environment in which people make decisions can be used to promote more sustainable diets. This finding has implications for the design of public policy and for the design of the built environment.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a panel of isogenic breast epithelial cells expressing oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the cancer cell surfaceome and its role in cancer. (Read more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. They also suggest that vote-by-mail is not a panacea for the problems of the US electoral system.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a global pandemic, with the development of vaccines and therapeutics being the only way to control the spread. The role of the viral accessory proteins in the disease severity and spread is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV. This study provides insight into the molecular basis of the disease severity and spread of the SARS-CoV-2 virus. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms of hypoxic cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important, but we don’t want to miss any. This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in this area and illustrate their use in some common statistical methods. We hope that this will help readers to better understand the strengths and limitations of the methods that they use every day.

Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are important signaling molecules that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. In the past decade, two additional RTKs have been identified, which are oncogenic drivers in human cancers. These two orphan RTKs, anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk), have been shown to be important in the development of the eye and the skin. Here, we show that these two orphan RTKs have physiological ligands in the zebrafish, which play an important role in the development of the eye and the skin. These results establish a physiological link between orphan RTKs and their ligands and demonstrate that particular ligands activate orphan RTKs in a tissue-specific context to induce development of the eye and skin in the zebrafish. This study provides a model system for the study of the function of orphan RTKs in the development of the eye and skin. This work also provides a model system for the study of the function of orphan RTKs in the development of the eye and skin.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular basis of T2D is well known, the treatment of T2D is still challenging. In this study, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. We also show that this interaction favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease with a multifactorial pathogenesis. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors, including hemodynamic environment. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate a critical role of YAP/TAZ in the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis, which may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a new perspective for the study of the role of YAP/TAZ in the regulation of vascular homeostasis and the development of vascular diseases. This study may also provide a new target for the treatment of atherosclerosis.

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be destructive. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be applied to other cities and other types of imagery, and we hope that it will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne pathogen that has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the recent outbreak has prompted global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the eclipse phase for ZIKV is likely short. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the peak viral load and shorten the time to undetectable viral load, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a widespread phenomenon that is considered a key indicator of the health of coral reefs. However, the processes underlying the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic status of the coral host is a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress leads to the release of ammonium, which in turn promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. These processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the external environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium loses its barrier function, leading to systemic infections and death. Here, we show that the tumorigenic response of the epithelium can also lead to the loss of the intestinal barrier. We show that the tumor-induced dysbiosis of the microbiome can trigger a regenerative response in the epithelium, leading to a vicious cycle of tumor growth and barrier dysfunction. Our work identifies a mechanism by which the tumorigenic response of the epithelium can lead to the loss of the intestinal barrier, and it highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work may help in the development of new strategies to treat cancer and prevent the development of intestinal cancer. It may also help in the development of new strategies to control the microbiome. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is an important component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous. We find that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and to reestablish tumor growth in mice. Furthermore, we show that the humanized anti-ROR1 antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduce the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impair the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is a matter of debate. Here we show that the start of deglaciation was linked to a volcanic eruption, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes that were similar to those observed over Antarctica today.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poor and undernourished. However, the high dependence of poor and rural communities on inland fisheries in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors highlights the need for improved management. Our data can be used to identify areas where fisheries are a priority for conservation and restoration. This can help to protect the food security of vulnerable populations and the biodiversity of river ecosystems.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable Mo-based oxide is designed to deliver a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3

The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the regenerative capacity is limited, and regeneration is often unsuccessful after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the mammalian CNS has the capacity to regenerate, even after long periods of inactivity, and that this capacity can be restored by conditioning the nervous system to a state of activity.

The process of recombination is essential for the evolution of genomes, and the distribution of recombination activity is a fundamental feature of the genome. However, the distribution of recombination activity in plants has remained elusive. Here, we use a population of wild monkeyflowers to precisely locate recombination events in a flowering plant. We find that recombination activity in plants is highly polarized, with peaks near the start of genes and a sharp decline in recombination activity within genes. These results provide a detailed view of recombination activity in a flowering plant, and may have implications for the evolution of the genome. (Read more)

The brain is organized in networks of functionally related regions. The identification of these networks is a fundamental step in understanding the function of the brain. Here, we show that the resting state of the brain can be used to identify reproducible networks in healthy and disease populations. We also show that the resting state of the brain can be used to monitor the progression of disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the best-known modification of messenger RNA (mRNA). However, the existence of other 5′ modifications in eukaryotes has been debated. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ NAD+ cap structure in yeast. We show that NAD+ cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs, and that it is produced cotranscriptionally. This discovery broadens our understanding of the diversity of 5′ modifications in eukaryotes and raises the possibility that the NAD+ cap could modulate mRNA stability and translation. The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) was a landmark study in the field of diabetes research. It showed that intensive therapy could prevent the development of diabetes complications. However, the mechanisms behind this effect are still not fully understood. Here we show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years after the end of the DCCT, and that these loci are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a new epigenetic marker for the study of diabetes complications. This marker could be used in the future to study the effects of new therapies and to predict the risk of complications in the future.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of the recently identified cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with high morbidity and mortality. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with the presence of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier dysfunction and in the development of psychological symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is unclear. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the diverse mixture of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of tomato flavor and opens the door to the development of new strategies for improving the flavor of tomato and other fruit. (Show more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the field. Here we use high-throughput experiments to show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper as temperatures deviate from ambient conditions, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This result is driven by two processes linked to the thermal tolerance curves of species, indicating that the impacts of environmental warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are likely to be more profound than previously thought. Our results highlight the importance of considering the effects of climate change on the thermal tolerance of species in order to understand the impacts of biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to represent different aspects of space. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to represent the local environment, are anatomically distinct from other cell types, and that they are strongly coupled among themselves. These findings provide a framework for understanding the organization of MEC cell types and their function in navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This is a unique means of flowering regulation, which is likely to be important for the synchronization of flowering in the host–parasite interaction.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The disease is associated with the loss of dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra and with the development of motor and nonmotor symptoms. Here, we describe a previously unidentified subsystem of the nigral system that is affected in Parkinson’s disease and other disorders. We show that the subsystem is formed by striosomes, which are specialized neurons in the substantia nigra, and their output, striosomes’ striosomes, which are densely packed with their output, dopamine-containing neurons. The subsystem is formed by striosomes’ striosomes’ bouquet-like arborizations, which target dopamine-containing dendrites and their cell bodies. The subsystem is likely critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others, and we do so by reading their minds. In this study, we show that the speed at which we respond to others is a signal of how connected we feel to them. This signal is used by others to assess the quality of our connections, and it is used by us to assess the quality of our own connections. This study provides a new way to understand the nature of social connection, and it provides a new way to understand the nature of human communication.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for setting the heart rate, and their function is tightly regulated by the heart’s internal and external clocks. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the internal and external clocks in SANCs. STIM1 is selectively expressed in SANCs and is required for the maintenance of SAN function. Our study reveals that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links the content of sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ stores with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant physiology has been debated. Although Si has been shown to enhance resistance against abiotic stresses, the role of Si in mediating resistance against insect herbivores has not been well documented. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances resistance against the rice leaffolder in rice plants, and that this effect is dependent on jasmonate (JA) signaling. Our results suggest that Si may act as a priming signal for JA-mediated defense responses against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant resistance against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a sustained increase in neural activity. However, this view is challenged by evidence that short-term synaptic facilitation may also play a role in memory. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of bioengineering tools for plant biology. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenging task due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we demonstrate the delivery of biomolecules to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the development of bioengineering tools for plant biology. (Show more)

Eutrophication is a global problem that is driven by human activities, including the excessive loading of nitrogen and phosphorus to aquatic ecosystems. In the United States, the majority of nutrient loading to lakes comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that small tributaries can be important sources of nutrients to large water bodies, especially in coastal areas. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to small watersheds, as they may play a disproportionate role in driving coastal eutrophication. This could help protect valuable nearshore ecosystems and support the sustainable use of valuable freshwater resources.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This finding is relevant to the study of the dynamics of complex systems, where the availability of rare configurations may be a common feature.

NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) are a class of autoimmune encephalitis that can cause a wide range of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. However, the mechanisms of these paroxysms are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic dynamics of the brain, which can then predispose the brain to paroxysmal activity. We also show that the same changes in the brain can be tolerated in a model of the brain in the absence of NMDAR-Abs. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same changes in the brain can be tolerated in the absence of NMDAR-Abs, and thus may be a mechanism for the EEG abnormalities to resolve. This may help explain the clinical variability of NMDAR-Abs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming, which is unprecedented in the last 2,000 y. The cause of this warming is still debated, but it is likely that the warming is related to a rise in atmospheric CO2. The rise in CO2 is, in turn, related to the release of organic carbon (C) from the ocean floor, which is a natural process. However, the release of C during the last deglaciation is unprecedented in the last 2,000 y. We show that the release of C during the last deglaciation is linked to a global warming event, which is also unprecedented in the last 2,000 y.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. This study is important for the palm oil industry, as well as for the global movement toward sustainable production and consumption. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis. It is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 evolutionarily conserved subunits, and the regulation of the exocyst complex is essential for the regulation of exocytosis. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major focus of research. In many species, sex is determined by a single locus, but in others, multiple loci interact to produce more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two alleles produce four possible sex classes. We find that the modular interplay of sex determination alleles results in variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and tank behaviors. The modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by multiple interacting sex determination alleles provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and photodegrading species. The retina is also challenged by the presence of iron, which can be a source of reactive oxygen species. We show that the presence of iron can promote the photodegradation of retinal pigment epithelial-derived species that are implicated in the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration and other retinal diseases. They also suggest that the presence of iron may be a target for the treatment of retinal diseases. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a central topic in ecology. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered an evolutionary dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, is linked to the evolution of morphological and functional innovations in their tentacles. Our findings help us understand how specialization has shaped the structure of present-day food webs. They also help us to understand how morphological evolution has shaped the diversity of feeding strategies in animals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The hominin hand is characterized by a suite of derived features that are absent in early hominins. These features are present in the fossil record of Middle Pleistocene and recent humans, but the origin of the suite is unclear because of the paucity of hominin hand fossils in the time interval between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand, was present in a fossil from East Africa ∼1.42 My old. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the origin of a key derived characteristic of the modern human hand and suggests that the suite of derived features arose early in the genus Homo. This finding has implications for understanding the evolution of the human hand and the emergence of modern human behavior. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), a key enzyme in one-carbon metabolism. We show that the inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that the inhibitor is effective in cancer cell lines, but not in normal cell lines. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type that is notoriously difficult to treat. Thus, our work identifies a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited for cancer therapy. This work also provides a useful platform for the development of new inhibitors of SHMT. Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the loss of natural landscapes is often seen as a threat to people’s livelihoods and food security. However, there is a growing body of literature that shows that having access to natural landscapes can improve people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This study shows that deforestation can have negative impacts on people’s diets, and that the loss of natural landscapes can have positive impacts. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Mechanization has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural machinery, allowing for higher output of food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
